{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{about|the Semitic letter|the 5th-century Cornish saint also known as Teth|Saint Tetha}} {{Phoenician glyph|letname=Tet|previouslink=Heth|previousletter=Het|nextlink=Yodh|nextletter=Yodh|archar={{lang|ar|Ø·}}|sychar=Ü›|hechar={{Hebrew|×˜}}|amchar=teth|gechar=áŒ |phchar=teth|grchar=Î˜|lachar=-|cychar=[[Ñ²]]|ipa=tË¤|num=9|gem=9}} '''Teth''', also written as '''{{Transl|sem|á¹¬Ä“th}}''' or '''Tet''', is a [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] á¹¬Ä“t [[File:Phoenician_teth.svg|10px]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] á¹¬Ä“t {{Hebrew|×˜}}, [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] á¹¬Ä“th [[File:Teth.svg|10px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] á¹¬Ä“á¹¯ Ü›, and [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] {{Transl|ar|DIN|á¹¬ÄÊ¾}} {{lang|ar|Ø·}}. It is the 16th letter of the modern Arabic alphabet. The [[Persian language|Persian]] á¹­a is pronounced as a hard "t" sound and is the 19th letter in the modern [[Persian alphabet]]. The Phoenician letter also gave rise to the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[theta]] ({{lang|el|Î˜}}), originally an [[aspirated consonant|aspirated]] [[voiceless alveolar stop]] but now used for the [[voiceless dental fricative]]. The Arabic letter is sometimes transliterated as ''tah'' in English,{{cite web |url=https://www.compart.com/en/unicode/U+FEC4 |title=â€œï»„â€ U+FEC4 Arabic Letter Tah Medial Form Unicode Character |website=comport|date= |author= |accessdate= 7 June 2019}} for example in [[Arabic script in Unicode]]. The sound value of Teth is {{IPAslink|tË¤}}, one of the Semitic [[emphatic consonant]]s. ==Origins== The Phoenician letter name {{Transl|sem|á¹­Ä“th}} means "wheel", but the letter possibly (according to Brian Colless{{cn|date=November 2017}}) continues a [[Proto-Sinaitic script|Middle Bronze Age]] glyph named {{Transl|sem|á¹­ab}} "good", ''Tav'' in Aramaic and ''Tov'' {{Hebrew|×˜×•×‘}} in Hebrew, ''á¹­ayyib'' {{lang|ar|Ø·ÙÙŠÙ‘Ø¨}} in modern Arabic, based on the ''nfr'' "good" [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|hieroglyph]]: F35 Jewish scripture books about the "holy letters" from the 10th century and on discuss the connection or origin of the letter Teth with the word Tov,This was especially emphasized ever since the late 1600s after the [[Baal Shem Tov]] became influential, since the letter Teth was in his Acronym standing for Tov, and goodness was part of his philosophy. and the [[acrostic]] poems of the Bible use 'Tov' to depict the letter.e.g. Psalm 119:65-72 ==Arabic á¹­ÄÊ¾== The letter is named ''{{transl|ar|ALA-LC|á¹­ÄÊ¾ }}''; [[Modern Standard Arabic]] pronunciation: {{IPA|/tË¤/}}. {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø·}} ==Hebrew Tet== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" |colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !|[[Serif]] !! [[sans-Serif]] !! [[Monospaced]]!![[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]]!![[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- |width=20%|×˜ |width=20%|×˜ |width=20%|×˜ |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Tet handwriting.svg|24px]] |width=20%|[[File:Rashi-tet.png|35px]] |} The Hebrew spelling of name of the letter: {{Hebrew|×˜Öµ×™×ª}} ===Hebrew pronunciation=== In [[Hebrew language|Modern Hebrew]], Tet represents a [[voiceless alveolar plosive]] {{IPA|/t/}}, although this can be [[Pharyngealisation|pharyngealized]] to produce {{IPA|[tË¤]}} in traditional [[Yemenite Jews|Temani]] and [[Sephardi]] pronunciation. ===Significance=== In [[gematria]], Tet represents the number nine. When followed by an apostrophe, it means 9,000. The most common example of this usage is in the numbers of the [[Hebrew calendar|Hebrew years]] (e.g., {{Hebrew|×˜'×ª×©× ×“}} in [[Arabic numerals|numbers]] would be the [[Calendar date|date]] 9754). As well, in gematria, the number 15 is written with Tet and [[Waw (letter)|Vav]], (9+6) to avoid the normal construction [[Yodh|Yud]] and [[He (letter)|Hei]] (10+5) which spells a [[Names of God in Judaism|name of God]]. Similarly, 16 is written with Tet and [[Zayin]] (9+7) instead of [[Yodh|Yud]] and [[Waw (letter)|Vav]] (10+6) to avoid spelling part of the [[Tetragrammaton]]. Tet is also one of the seven letters which receive special crowns (called ''[[Tag (Hebrew writing)|tagin]]'') when written in a [[Sefer Torah]]. See [[Shin (letter)|Shin]], [[Ayin]], [[Gimmel]], [[Nun (letter)|Nun]], [[Zayin]], and [[Tzade|Tzadi]]. ==Similar symbols== A symbol similar to the Phoenician teth is used for the [[tensor product]], as \otimes, but this is presumably an independent development, by modification of the [[multiplication sign]] Ã—. The Hebrew {{Hebrew|×˜}} is also visually similar to the letter [[Æ²]]. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D8|name1=Hebrew Letter Tet |0637|name2=Arabic Letter Tah |071B|name3=Syriac Letter Teth |0808|name4=Samaritan Letter Tit }} {{charmap |10389|name1=Ugaritic Letter Tet |10848|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter Teth |10908|name3=Phoenician Letter Tet }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat|×˜}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Arabic language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]]

{{Phoenician glyph|letname=Tsade|previouslink=Pe (letter)|previousletter=Pe|nextlink=Qoph|nextletter=Qoph|archar=ØµÙ€,Øµ|sychar= Ü¨ |gechar=áŒ¸|hechar=×¦,×¥|amchar=sade 1|phchar=sade|grchar=Ïº Ï |lachar=-|cychar=Ğ¦ Ğ§|ipa=sË¤ (tÍ¡s)|num=18|gem=90}} '''Tsade''' (also spelled '''{{lang|sem-Latn|á¹¢ade}}''', {{lang|sem-Latn|'''á¹¢ÄdÄ“'''}}, '''{{lang|sem-Latn|á¹¢addi}}''', '''{{transl|ar|á¹¢ad}}''', '''Tzadi''', '''Sadhe''', '''Tzaddik''') is the eighteenth [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] á¹¢ÄdÄ“ [[File:Phoenician_sade.svg|12px]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] á¹¢Ädi {{Lang|he|×¦}}, [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] á¹¢Äá¸Ä“ [[File:Sade_1.svg| 12 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] á¹¢Äá¸Ä“ Ü¨, [[Ge'ez script|Ge'ez]] á¹¢Ã¤dÃ¤y áŒ¸, and [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] {{Transl|ar|DIN|á¹¢Äd}} {{Lang|ar|Øµ}}. Its oldest sound value is probably {{IPA|/sË¤/}}, although there is a variety of pronunciation in different modern Semitic languages and their dialects. It represents the coalescence of three [[Proto-Semitic]] "[[emphatic consonant]]s" in [[Canaanite language|Canaanite]]. [[Arabic language|Arabic]], which kept the phonemes separate, introduced variants of {{Transl|ar|DIN|á¹£Äd}} and {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[á¹­ÄÊ¾]]}} to express the three (see {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[á¸Äd]]}}, {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[áº“ÄÊ¾]]}}). In Aramaic, these emphatic consonants coalesced instead with ''[[Ayin|Ê¿ayin]]'' and ''[[Teth|á¹­Ä“t]]'', respectively, thus Hebrew ''ereá¹£'' ××¨×¥ (earth) is ''araÊ¿'' ××¨×¢ in Aramaic. The Phoenician letter is continued in the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[San (letter)|San]] (Ïº) and possibly [[Sampi]] (Ï ), and in [[Old Italic alphabet|Etruscan]] ğŒ‘ ''Åš''. It may have inspired the form of the letter [[Tse (letter)|Tse]] in the [[Glagolitic alphabet|Glagolitic]] and [[Cyrillic alphabet]]s. The corresponding letter of the [[Ugaritic alphabet]] is ğ• ''á¹£ade''. The letter is named "tsadek" in Yiddish,{{cite book |last=Weinreich |first=Uriel |date=1968 |title=Modern English-Yiddish Yiddish-English Dictionary |url= |location=New York |publisher=McGraw-Hill Book Co. |page=453 |isbn=07-0690380-3}} and Hebrew speakers often give it a similar name as well. This name for the letter probably originated from a fast recitation of the alphabet (i.e., "''tsadi'', ''[[qoph]]''" â†’ "''tsadiq'', ''qoph''"), influenced by the Hebrew word ''[[tzadik]]'', meaning "righteous person".{{Cite web | title = The Letter Tsade: Righteousness and Modesty | url=http://www.arachim.org/Index.asp?ArticleID=794&CategoryID=164 | language=Hebrew | accessdate = 5 December 2010 }} ==Origins== The origin of {{transl|sem|á¹£ade}} is unclear. It may have come from a [[Proto-Sinaitic script]] based on a pictogram of a plant, perhaps a [[Cyperus papyrus|papyrus plant]], or a [[fish hook]] (in [[Modern Hebrew]], {{lang|he|×¦×“}} ''{{transl|he|tsad}}'' means "[he] hunt[ed]", and in Arabic {{lang|ar|ØµØ§Ø¯}} ''{{transl|ar|á¹£Äd}}'' means "[he] hunted"). ==Arabic á¹£Äd== {{See also2|the derived letter|{{lang|ar|[[á¸ŒÄd|Ø¶]]}} ({{transl|ar|DIN|á¸Äd}}).}} The letter is named ''{{Transl|ar|DIN|á¹£Äd }}''; [[Modern Standard Arabic]] [[Arabic phonology|pronunciation]]: {{IPA|/sË¤/}}. It is written in several ways depending in its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Øµ}} Surah [[Sad (surah)|''á¹¢Äd'']] of the [[Quran]] is named for this letter, which begins the surah. The phoneme is not native to [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Ottoman Turkish language|Ottoman Turkish]], or [[Urdu]], and its pronunciation in Arabic loanwords in these languages is not distinguishable from {{lang|ar|[[Ø³]]}} or {{lang|ar|[[Ø«]]}}; all of them are pronounced {{IPAblink|s}} or tÍ¡s. ==Hebrew tsadi== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" !colspan=6|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !rowspan=2|position
in

Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi script|Rashi
script]] |- !|Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- |width=15%|non-final |width=17%|×¦ |width=17%|×¦ |width=17%|×¦ |width=17%|[[File:Hebrew letter Tsadik handwriting.svg|25px]] |width=17%|[[File:Hebrew letter Tsadik-nonfinal Rashi.png|40px]] |- |width=15%|final |width=17%|×¥ |width=17%|×¥ |width=17%|×¥ |width=17%|[[File:Hebrew letter Tsadik-final handwriting.svg|21px]] |width=17%|[[File:Hebrew letter Tsadik-final Rashi.png|40px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{lang|he|×¦Ö¸×“Ö´×™}} or {{lang|he|×¦Ö¸×“Öµ×™}}. ===Name=== In [[Hebrew language|modern Hebrew]], the letter's name is ''Tsadi'' or ''á¹¢adi'', depending on whether the letter is transliterated as the common "ts" or the more scientific "á¹£". ===Variations=== {{transl|he|á¹¢adi}}, like [[Kaph]], [[Mem]], [[Pe (letter)|Pe]], and [[Nun (letter)|Nun]], has a final form, used at the end of words. Its shape changes from {{Hebrew|×¦}} to {{Hebrew|×¥}}. ===Pronunciation=== In [[Modern Hebrew]], ×¦ ''tsade'' represents a [[voiceless alveolar affricate]] {{IPAslink|tÍ¡s}}. This is the same in [[Yiddish]]. Historically, it likely represented a [[pharyngealisation|pharyngealized]] {{IPA|/tÍ¡sË¤/}}; which became {{IPAblink|tÍ¡s}} in [[Ashkenazi Jews|Ashkenazi]] pronunciation. A ''[[Hebrew numerals#Gershayim|geresh]]'' can also be placed after ''tsade'' ({{Hebrew|×¦×³ ; ×¥×³}}), giving it the sound {{IPAblink|tÍ¡Êƒ}}, e.g. {{Hebrew|×¦Ö´×³×™×¤Ö°Ö¼×¡}} ''{{transl|he|Äips}}'', meaning "chips". á¹¢ade appears as {{IPA|[sË¤]}} amongst [[Yemenite Jews]] and other Jews from the [[Middle East]]; the loss of [[affricate consonant|affricatisation]] is likely due to influence from Arabic. ===Significance=== In [[gematria]], {{transl|he|á¹¢adi}} represents the number 90. Its final form represents 900, but this is rarely used, [[Tau (letter)|Taw]], [[Tau (letter)|Taw]], and [[Qoph|Qof]] (400+400+100) being used instead. As an abbreviation, it stands for ''á¹£afon'', North. {{transl|he|á¹¢adi}} is also one of the seven letters that receive a special crown (called ''tagin'') when written in a [[Sefer Torah]]. See [[Shin (letter)|Shin]], [[â€˜Ayin]], {{transl|he|[[á¹¬eth|á¹¬et]]}}, [[Nun (letter)|Nun]], [[Zayin]], and [[Gimmel]]. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05E6|name1=Hebrew Letter Tsadi |05E5|name2=Hebrew Letter Final Tsadi |0635|name3=Arabic Letter Sad |0728|name4=Syriac Letter Sadhe |0811|name5=Samaritan Letter Tsaadiy }} {{charmap |10395|name1=Ugaritic Letter Sade |10851|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter Sadhe |10911|name3=Phoenician Letter Sade }} ==See also== *[[á¹¢]] *[[Z#Usage|Z â†’ Usage]] *[[Tse (Cyrillic)]] ==Notes== ==External links== {{commons category|×¦}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Arabic language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]] [[Category:Letters with final form]]

|} '''Tzere''' (also spelled ''Tsere'', ''Tzeirei'', ''Zere'', ''Zeire'', ''á¹¢erÃ®'', ''á¹¢erÃª'' etc.; {{lang-he-n|×¦Öµ×™×¨Öµ×™}}   {{IPA-he|tseËˆÉ¾e|IPA}}, sometimes {{Hebrew|×¦×™×¨×”}}) is a [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] [[niqqud]] [[vowel]] sign represented by two dots "â—ŒÖµ" underneath a letter. In modern Hebrew, tzere is pronounced the same as and indicates the [[phoneme]] /e/ which is the same as the "e" sound in s'''e'''ll and is [[Romanization of Hebrew|transliterated]] as an "e". There was a distinction in [[Tiberian Hebrew]] between [[segol]] and Tzere. ==Usage== Tzere is usually written in these cases: * In final stressed closed syllables: ×Ö·×—Ö°×©Öµ××‘ ({{IPA|[maÄ§ËˆÊƒev]}}, ''computer''), ×¡Ö´×¤ÖµÖ¼×¨ ({{IPA|[sipËˆpeÊ]}}, ''he told''; without niqqud ×¡×™×¤×¨). Also in final syllables closed by guttural letters with an added furtive [[patach]]: ×Ö·×˜Ö°×‘ÖµÖ¼×¢Ö· ({{IPA|[matËˆbeaÊ•]}}, ''coin''), ×©×•Ö¹×›Öµ×—Ö· ({{IPA|[ÊƒoËˆÏ‡eaÄ§]}}, ''forgetting''). Notable exceptions to this rule are: ** The personal suffixes Ö¾×ªÖ¶× ({{IPA|[tem]}}, 2 pl. m.), Ö¾×ªÖ¶×Ÿ ({{IPA|[ten]}}, 2 pl. f.), Ö¾×›Ö¶× ({{IPA|[Ï‡em]}}, 2 pl. m.), Ö¾×›Ö¶×Ÿ ({{IPA|[Ï‡en]}}, 2 pl. f.), Ö¾×”Ö¶× ({{IPA|[hem]}}, 3 pl. m.), Ö¾×”Ö¶×Ÿ ({{IPA|[hen]}}, 3 pl. f.) are written with segol. (But the words ×”Öµ× ({{IPA|[hem]}}, ''they m.''), ×”Öµ×Ÿ ({{IPA|[hen]}}, ''they f.'') are written with Tzere.) ** The words ×Ö±×Ö¶×ª ({{IPA|[eËˆmet]}}, ''truth''), ×‘Ö·Ö¼×¨Ö°×–Ö¶×œ ({{IPA|[baÊËˆzel]}}, ''iron''), ×’Ö·Ö¼×¨Ö°×–Ö¶×Ÿ ({{IPA|[É¡aÊËˆzen]}}, ''axe''), ×›Ö·Ö¼×¨Ö°×Ö¶×œ ({{IPA|[kaÊËˆmel]}}, ''[[Carmel (biblical settlement)|Carmel]]'', ''gardenland''), ×¢Ö²×¨Ö¸×¤Ö¶×œ ({{IPA|[Ê•aÊaËˆfel]}}, ''fog'') are written with segol. ** The word ×‘ÖµÖ¼×Ÿ ({{IPA|[ben]}}, ''son, boy'') is written with tzere in the absolute state, but with segol in the [[construct state]]: ×‘Ö¶Ö¼×ŸÖ¾. In the Bible this rule also applies to other words which end in tzere, when they are written with [[maqaf]].Academy Decisions: Grammar, 2nd edition, Â§1.4 ×‘. * In non-final, unstressed open syllables: ×¢Öµ× Ö¸×‘ ({{IPA|[Ê•eËˆnav]}}, ''grape''), ×ªÖµÖ¼×‘Ö¸×” ({{IPA|[teËˆva]}}, ''chest'', ''ark''; without niqqud ×ª×™×‘×”). * In the first (stressed) syllable of about 70 [[segolate]] words, among them ×—Öµ×œÖ¶×§ ({{IPA|[ËˆÄ§eleq]}}, ''part''), ×¡Öµ×¤Ö¶×¨ ({{IPA|[ËˆsefeÊ]}}, ''book''), ×¢Öµ×“Ö¶×Ÿ ({{IPA|[ËˆÊ•eden]}}, ''Eden'').A full list appears in [http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/hahlatot/GrammarDecisions/1/Pages/Ch1D059.aspx Academy Decisions: Grammar, 2nd edition, Â§1.4 ×›]. In other â€“ much more numerous â€“ segolate words the first {{IPA|[e]}} sound is a [[segol]]. * In final open syllables, when the [[mater lectionis]] is [[yodh|yod]] (×™) or [[aleph]] (×‎): ×‘Ö°Ö¼× Öµ×™Ö¾ ({{IPA|[bÉ™ne]}}, ''sons of''), ××•Ö¹×¦Öµ× ({{IPA|[moËˆtse]}}, ''finding''). When the mater lectionis is [[he (letter)|he]] (×”), the vowel sign is usually [[segol]], but tzere is written in the imperative and absolute infinitive forms of the verb, in nouns in construct state, and in the base form of several other nouns (see below for details). In declension tzere sometimes changes to other vowels or to [[shva]]. The full rules for these changes were formulated the Academy of the Hebrew Language. In modern Hebrew there are words which are [[homophone]]s and [[homograph]]s in spelling without niqqud, but are written differently with niqqud, the difference being segol and tzere. For example, ×¢Ö¶×¨Ö¶×‘ ''evening'' and ×¢Öµ×¨Ö¶×‘ ''[[weft]]'' are both pronounced {{IPA|[ËˆÊ•eÊev]}} and written ×¢×¨×‘ without niqqud (these words also have different etymology). ==Writing tzere with and without matres lectionis== {{Main article|Mater lectionis}} ''Tzere'' can be written with and without matres lectionis. The most prominent mater lectionis for tzere is [[Yodh|Yod]] ({{Hebrew|×™}}), and in some cases it is used with the letters [[aleph]] ({{Hebrew|×}}) and [[he (letter)|he]] ({{Hebrew|×”}}). Standard spelling rules mandate only one way to spell every word with or without the Yod after tzere. Although in standard modern pronunciation the sound of tzere with or without the Yod is the same, it may change the word's meaning in a written text (see below). ===Standard usage without Yod=== ''Tzere'' can be written by itself without mater lectionis, in which case it is called ''tzere á¸¥aser'' ("lacking tzere"), for example in the word {{Hebrew|×–Öµ×¨}} ({{IPA|[zeÉ¾]}}, ''wreath''). In this case, in text without niqqud the vowel {{IPA|[e]}} is usually not written at all: ×–×¨. This word can be also vocalized as {{Hebrew|×–Ö¸×¨}} ({{IPA|[zaÉ¾]}}, ''stranger'') and the reader has to guess the right pronunciation according to the context. According to the standardized Hebrew spelling the letter Yod is sometimes written in texts without niqqud, when there is a grammatical reason for it; for example, the verb {{Hebrew|×ªÖµÖ¼×¢Ö¸×“Öµ×¨}} ({{IPA|[teÊ•aËˆdeÉ¾]}}, ''she will be absent'') is written without Yod in texts with niqqud, but the Yod is written in a text without niqqud: {{Hebrew|×ª×™×¢×“×¨}}. ===Standard usage with Yod=== ''Tzere'' with Yod is called "full tzere". When a full tzere is written in text with niqqud, the letter Yod must be written in text without niqqud. The main cases for writing the tzere with Yod are these: * Tzere is written with Yod to indicate the plural number of declined words, for example {{Hebrew|××•Ö¼×¦Ö¸×¨Öµ× ×•Ö¼}} means ''our product'' and {{Hebrew|××•Ö¼×¦Ö¸×¨Öµ×™× ×•Ö¼}} means ''our product'''s'''''; the standard pronunciation is the same: {{IPA|[mutsaËˆÉ¾enu]}}. * Tzere is written with Yod in words in which the Yod is a part of the [[Semitic root|root]]: ** Nouns, for example ×‘ÖµÖ¼×™×¦Ö¸×” ({{IPA|[beËˆtsa]}}, ''egg''), root ×‘Ö¾×™Ö¾×¦‎; ×–Öµ×™×ªÖ´×™× ({{IPA|[zeËˆtim]}}, ''olives'', the plural of ×–Ö·×™Ö´×ª), root ×–Ö¾×™Ö¾×ª‎, ×Öµ×™×“Ö¸×¢ ({{IPA|[meËˆdaÊ•]}}, ''information''), root ×™Ö¾×“Ö¾×¢. Tzere is also traditionally written with Yod in several other words, the roots of which are rarely used productively to form other words, among them ×¤Ö°Ö¼×¡Öµ×™×¤Ö¸×¡ ({{IPA|[pÉ™seËˆfas]}}, ''mosaic''), ×§Öµ×™×¡Ö¸× ({{IPA|[qeËˆsam]}}, ''sliver'') and the word "tzere" itself â€“ ×¦Öµ×™×¨Öµ×™ ({{IPA|[tseËˆÉ¾e]}}).Academy Decisions: Grammar, 2nd edition, Â§1.4. ** Verbs, in which the last letter of the root is he (×œ×´×”), which is by convention treated as interchangeable with Yod,{{Cite GHG|75}}. for example × Ö´×‘Ö°× Öµ×™×ª ({{IPA|[nivËˆnet]}}, ''being built f.''), root ×‘Ö¾× Ö¾×” (or ×‘Ö¾× Ö¾×™). In Arabic the corresponding verbs are written with Ê¾alif maqá¹£Å«ra, which represents a similar interchange of the letters [[yÄÊ¾]] (ÙŠ) and [[Ê¾alif]] (Ø§). ** Some verbs in which the first letter of the root is Yod (×¤×´×™‎),{{Cite GHG|70}}. for example ×”Öµ×™×˜Ö´×™×‘ ({{IPA|[heËˆtiv]}}, ''he did well''), root ×™Ö¾×˜Ö¾×‘. * In standard spelling without niqqud Yod is written to represent the [e] sound in words formed in the pattern heCCeC (×”Ö¶×§Ö°×˜Öµ×œ), in which the first and the second consonants of the root merge, even though the vowel there is not tzere, but seggol, for example ×”Ö¶×©ÖµÖ¼×‚×’ ({{IPA|[hesËˆseÉ¡]}}, ''achievement''; root × Ö¾×©×‚Ö¾×’, without niqqud ×”×™×©×’). ===Nonstandard usage of Yod to represent tzere=== In texts with full niqqud â€“ mostly poetry, religious and children books â€“ tzere is usually written in accordance with the rules mandated by the Academy. The Academy defined some cases in which a Yod is added to texts without niqqud to signify an {{IPA|[e]}} sound, but in common usage Yod is often written or not written contrary to the standard. Some notable common deviations from the standard in which a Yod is added include: * Some words are often written with Yod in texts without niqqud, even though the Yod is not a part of the root and is not written in a text with niqqud. For example: ×Öµ×Ö·×“ ({{IPA|[meËˆmad]}}, ''dimension''), ×Öµ×¨Ö·×‘ ({{IPA|[meËˆÉ¾av]}}, ''[[Merab]]'', ''most''), ×©Öµ×‚×¢Ö¸×¨ ({{IPA|[seËˆÊ•aÉ¾]}}, ''hair'') are often written ××™××“‎, ××™×¨×‘ and ×©×™×¢×¨, even though the standard spelling without niqqud is ×××“‎, ××¨×‘‎, ×©×¢×¨. This goes further as the Yod is retained in declined forms of the word, which aren't written with tzere at all, but with shva; for example, the word ×©Ö°×‚×¢Ö¸×¨×•Ö¹×ª ({{IPA|[seÊ•aËˆÉ¾ot]}}, ''hairs'') is frequently written ×©×™×¢×¨×•×ª, although the vowel of the ×© is shva (the standard spelling is ×©×¢×¨×•×ª). * Words in the pattern CÉ™CeCa (×§Ö°×˜Öµ×œÖ¸×”) are often written with a Yod, even though it is not the standard. Examples include ×‘Ö°Ö¼×¨Öµ×›Ö¸×” ({{IPA|[bÉ™É¾eËˆÏ‡a]}}, ''pool''), ×’Ö°Ö¼× Öµ×‘Ö¸×” ({{IPA|[É¡É™neËˆva]}}, ''theft''), ×©Ö°×‚×¨Öµ×¤Ö¸×” ({{IPA|[sÉ™É¾eËˆfa]}}, ''burning''), which are often written ×‘×¨×™×›×”‎, ×’× ×™×‘×”‎, ×©×¨×™×¤×” instead of the standard ×‘×¨×›×”‎, ×’× ×‘×”‎, ×©×¨×¤×”. * Yod is often added in texts without niqqud to represent tzere in the future tense of verbs in which Yod is the first letter of the root, for example ×™Öµ×©Öµ××‘ ({{IPA|[yeËˆÊƒev]}}, ''he will sit'') is often written ×™×™×©×‘, although the standard spelling is ×™×©×‘. This spelling may also be vocalized ×™Ö¸×©Ö·××‘ ({{IPA|[yaËˆÊƒav]}}, ''he sat''), but adding a Yod doesn't solve the ambiguity â€“ ×™×™×©×‘ may be vocalized ×™Ö°×™Ö·×©Öµ××‘ ({{IPA|[yeËˆyaÊƒev]}}, ''he will settle'') and ×™Ö´×©Öµ××‘ ({{IPA|[yiËˆÊƒev]}}, ''he settled''). Because of the many potential ambiguities, the Academy suggests adding vocalization in such cases. * Several other (non-comprehensive) examples: ** The standard spelling of the plural form of the word ×¤Ö°Ö¼×¨Ö´×™ ({{IPA|[pÉ™É¾i]}}, ''fruit'') is ×¤ÖµÖ¼×¨×•Ö¹×ª ({{IPA|[peÉ¾ot]}}) with niqqud and ×¤×¨×•×ª without niqqud, but it is often written ×¤×™×¨×•×ª‎ (×¤×¨×•×ª may also mean ×¤Ö¸Ö¼×¨×•Ö¹×ª {{IPA|[paËˆÉ¾ot]}} ''cows''). ** The words ×Öµ×–×•Ö¹×¨ ({{IPA|[eËˆzoÉ¾]}}, ''zone''), ×”Öµ×¤Ö¶×šÖ° ({{IPA|[ËˆhefeÏ‡]}}, ''contrary''; also ×”Ö¶×¤Ö¶×šÖ°‎), ×ªÖµÖ¼×›Ö¶×£ ({{IPA|[ËˆteÏ‡ef]}}, ''immediately''; also ×ªÖ¶Ö¼×›Ö¶×£) are sometimes spelled ××™×–×•×¨‎, ×”×™×¤×š‎, ×ª×™×›×£, although the standard spelling without niqqud is ××–×•×¨‎, ×”×¤×š‎, ×ª×›×£. (In the ''[[Even-Shoshan Dictionary|Even-Shoshan]]'' dictionary ×ª×™×›×£ refers to ×ªÖ¶Ö¼×›Ö¶×£; in the ''Rav-Millim'' dictionary it is the main entry.) Some notable common deviations from the standard in which a Yod is not written include: * According to the modern spelling rules, the Academy mandates writing a Yod in some cases in which the vowel {{IPA|[i]}} changes to {{IPA|[e]}} for grammatical reasons. (Not writing the Yod is correct according to the old ''ktiv haser'' spelling.) For example: ** In the future, imperative and infinitive forms of verbs in [[binyan]] ''nif'al'', the vowel of the prefix is usually {{IPA|[i]}}, which in standard spelling without niqqud is written with a Yod: ×œÖ°×”Ö´×–Ö¸Ö¼×”Öµ×¨ ({{IPA|[lÉ™hizzaËˆheÉ¾]}}, ''to be cautious''), standard spelling without niqqud: ×œ×”×™×–×”×¨. This vowel changes to {{IPA|[e]}} before the guttural letters ×‎, ×”‎, ×—‎, ×¢‎, ×¨‎: ×œÖ°×”Öµ×¨Ö¸×“Öµ× ({{IPA|[lÉ™heÉ¾aËˆdem]}}, ''to fall asleep''), standard spelling without niqqud: ×œ×”×™×¨×“×. Sometimes, however, verbs with both {{IPA|[i]}} and {{IPA|[e]}} are written without a Yod in texts without niqqud: ×œ×”×–×”×¨‎, ×œ×”×¨×“×. ** In nouns of the pattern CiCCuC, such as ×¡Ö´×¤Ö¼×•Ö¼×§ ({{IPA|[sipËˆpuq]}}, ''satisfaction'', without niqqud ×¡×™×¤×•×§) the vowel {{IPA|[i]}} also changes to {{IPA|[e]}} before guttural letters: ×¤ÖµÖ¼×¨×•Ö¼×©× ({{IPA|[peËˆÉ¾uÊƒ]}}, ''commentary''), ×ªÖµÖ¼××•Ö¼×¨ ({{IPA|[teËˆÊ”uÉ¾]}}, ''description''), without niqqud: ×¤×™×¨×•×©‎, ×ª×™××•×¨, but sometimes ×¤×¨×•×©‎, ×ª××•×¨. * The Yod is sometimes omitted from words, the last letter of whose root is ×”‎. This is a mistake, because in these verbs the Yod is written in texts with niqqud. For example: ×”×•Ö¹×“Öµ×™×ªÖ´×™ ({{IPA|[hoËˆdeti]}}, ''I thanked'', root ×™Ö¾×“Ö¾×”‎), × Ö¶×”Ö±× Öµ×™× ×•Ö¼ ({{IPA|[neheËˆnenu]}}, ''we enjoyed'', root ×”Ö¾× Ö¾×”) are sometimes incorrectly spelled ×”×•×“×ª×™‎, × ×”× × ×•. ===Tzere with aleph and he=== The letter aleph (×) is the mater lectionis after tzere in the middle or the end of the word when it is a part of the root: ××•Ö¹×¦Öµ× ({{IPA|[moËˆtse]}}, ''finding m.''), ××•Ö¹×¦Öµ××ª ({{IPA|[moËˆtset]}}, ''finding f.''). The letter he (×”) is very rarely used as a mater lectionis for {{IPA|[e]}} in the middle of the word. The notable example for this is the word ×™Ö°×¤Öµ×”×¤Ö´×™Ö¸Ö¼×” ({{IPA|[jÉ™fefiËˆja]}}, ''pretty''), in which the two last letters of the root (×™Ö¾×¤Ö¾×”) are [[reduplication|reduplicated]]. It can also be spelled ×™×¤×”Ö¾×¤×™×” (fem.; so in the Bible, {{bibleverse||Jeremiah|46:20||}}) or ×™×¤×™×¤×™×”. The letter he (×”) is often used as a mater lectionis for the vowel {{IPA|[e]}} in the end of the word, but the niqqud is usually segol. It is tzere in these cases: * In the [[construct state]] of nouns: absolute state ×©Ö¸×‚×“Ö¶×” ({{IPA|[saËˆde]}}, ''field''), but construct state ×©Ö°×‚×“Öµ×”Ö¾ ({{IPA|[sÉ™de]}}). * In the imperative and absolute infinitive forms of the verb: future form ×™Ö°×’Ö·×œÖ¶Ö¼×” ({{IPA|[jÉ™É¡alËˆle]}}, ''he will discover''), but ×’Ö·Ö¼×œÖµÖ¼×” ({{IPA|[É¡alËˆle]}}, ''discover!''); future form ×ªÖ·Ö¼×¨Ö°×‘Ö¶Ö¼×” ({{IPA|[taÉ¾Ëˆbe]}}, ''she shall increase, make many''), absolute infinitive ×”Ö·×¨Ö°×‘ÖµÖ¼×” ({{IPA|[haÉ¾Ëˆbe]}}, ''many''). * In some words, among them ×Ö·×™ÖµÖ¼×” ({{IPA|[ajËˆje]}}, ''where?''), ×Ö·×¨Ö°×™Öµ×” ({{IPA|[aÉ¾Ëˆje]}}, ''lion''), ×”Ö´× ÖµÖ¼×” ({{IPA|[hinËˆne]}}, ''here!''), ×™Ö¸×©Ö°××¤Öµ×” ({{IPA|[jaÊƒÉ™Ëˆfe]}}, ''jasper''; also ×™Ö¸×©Ö°××¤Ö¶×”‎), Ö¾×¢Ö¶×©Ö°×‚×¨Öµ×” ({{IPA|[Ê•esËˆre]}}, ''-teen f.'').A grammatical supplement to the Even-Shoshan Dictionary (2003 edition), Â§15. ==Pronunciation== The following table contains the [[pronunciation]] and [[transliteration]] of the different tzeres in reconstructed historical forms and [[dialect]]s using the [[help:IPA|International Phonetic Alphabet]]. pages.title: Waw (letter)
pages.text:
{{About|the Semitic letter|other uses|WAW (disambiguation){{!}}WAW}} {{Phoenician glyph|letname=Waw|previouslink=He (letter)|previousletter=He|nextlink=Zayin|nextletter=Zayin|archar={{lang|ar|Ùˆ}}|sychar=Ü˜|hechar={{Hebrew|×•}}|amchar=waw|gechar=á‹ˆ|phchar=waw|grchar=[[Digamma|Ïœ]] [[Upsilon|Î¥]]|lachar=F V U W Y|cychar=Ğ£|ipa=w, v, o, u|num=6|gem=6}} '''Waw/Vav''' ({{transl|sem|wÄw}} "hook") is the sixth [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the [[Abjad|Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] ''wÄw'' [[File:Phoenician waw.svg|10px]], [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] ''waw'' [[File:Waw.svg|10 px]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] ''[[:wikt:×•×™×´×•|vav]]'' {{Hebrew|×•}}, [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] ''waw'' Ü˜ and [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] ''[[:wikt:ÙˆØ§Ùˆ|wÄw]]'' {{lang|ar|Ùˆ}} (sixth in [[abjadi order]]; 27th in modern Arabic order). It represents the consonant {{IPAblink|w}} in original [[Hebrew]], and {{IPAblink|v}} in modern Hebrew, as well as the vowels {{IPAblink|u}} and {{IPAblink|o}}. In text with [[niqqud]], a dot is added to the left or on top of the letter to indicate, respectively, the two vowel pronunciations. It is the origin of Greek [[Ïœ]] (digamma) and [[Î¥]] (upsilon), Latin [[F]] and [[V]], and the derived "Latin"- or "Roman"- alphabet letters [[U]], [[W]], and [[Y]]. ==Origin== The letter likely originated with an [[Egyptian hieroglyph]] which represented [[List of Egyptian hieroglyphs by common name: M-Z#M|the word ''mace'']] (transliterated as á¸¥(dj)): T3 In Modern Hebrew, the word '''{{lang|he|{{linktext|×•Ö¸×•}}}}''' ''vav'' is used to mean both "hook" and the letter's name (the name is also written '''{{lang|he|{{linktext|×•×™×´×•}}}}'''). ==Arabic wÄw{{anchor|Arabic}}== {{Infobox grapheme |name=wÄw |letter=Ùˆ |variations= |image= |imagesize=200 |imagealt= |script=[[Arabic script]] |type=[[Abjad]] |typedesc= |language=[[Arabic language]] |phonemes={{IPAslink|w}}, {{IPAslink|uË}} |unicode= |alphanumber=4 |number= |usageperiod= |children= |equivalents= |associates= |direction=Right-to-left }} The letter '''{{lang|ar|Ùˆ}}''' is named '''{{lang|ar|ÙˆØ§Ùˆ}}''' ''wÄw'' and is written in several ways depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ùˆ}} WÄw is used to represent four distinct phonetic features: *A consonant, pronounced as a [[voiced labial-velar approximant]] '''{{IPA|/w/}}''', which is the case whenever it is at the beginnings of words, but normally occurs also in the middle or end. *A [[vowel length|long]] '''{{IPA|/uË/}}'''. The preceding consonant could either have no diacritic or a short-wÄw-vowel mark, [[damma]], to aid in the pronunciation by hinting to the following long vowel. *A [[vowel length|long]] '''{{IPA|/oË/}}''' In many [[varieties of Arabic|dialects]], as a result of the [[monophthong]]ization that underwent the diphthong {{IPA|/aw/}} in most of the words. *A part of a [[diphthong]], '''{{IPA|/aw/}}'''. In this case it has no diacritic, but could be marked with a sukun in some traditions. The preceding consonant could either have no diacritic or have {{Transl|ar|DIN|[[fatá¸¥a]]}} sign, hinting to the first vowel {{IPA|/a/}} in the diphthong. As a vowel, ''wÄw'' can serve as the carrier of a [[hamza]]: {{lang|ar|Ø¤}}. ''WÄw'' serves several functions in [[Arabic language|Arabic]]. Perhaps foremost among them is that it is the primary [[grammatical conjunction|conjunction]] in Arabic, equivalent to "and"; it is usually [[prefix]]ed to other conjunctions, such as {{lang|ar|ÙˆÙÙ„ÙÙƒÙÙ†}} ''wa-lÄkin'', meaning "but". Another function is the "[[oath]]", by preceding a noun of great significantly valued by the speaker. It is often literally translatable to "By..." or "I swear to...", and is often used in the [[Qur'an]] in this way, and also in the generally fixed construction {{lang|ar|ÙˆØ§Ù„Ù„Ù‡}} ''wallÄh'' ("By [[Allah]]!" or "I swear to God!"). === Derived letters === {{Arabic alphabet shapes|ۋ}} With an additional triple dot diacritic above ''waw'', the letter then named ''ve'' is used to represent distinctively the consonant {{IPAslink|v}} sometimes in Arabic-based [[SoranÃ®|Sorani Kurdish]] and in [[Uyghur Arabic alphabet|Arabic-based]] [[Uyghur language|Uyghur]]. {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Û†}} {{IPAslink|o}} in Sorani Kurdish; {{IPAslink|v}} in [[Kazakh alphabets#Arabic|Arabic-based]] [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]]; {{IPAslink|Ã¸}} in Uyghur.
Thirty-fourth letter of the Azerbaijani Arabic script, represents Ã” {{IPAslink|É”}}.
It is also used for short vowel {{IPAslink|o}} or {{IPAslink|u}} in a lot of languages,{{specify|date=January 2015}} for example "u" in ''bull'' ({{lang|ar|Ø¨Û†Ù„}}) {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Û‰}} for {{IPAslink|oË}} or {{IPAslink|u}}, used in a lot of languages,{{specify|date=January 2015}} for example [[o]] in ''bold'' ({{lang|ar|Ø¨Û‰Ù„Ø¯}}) {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ûˆ}} {{IPAslink|y}} in Uyghur and also in other languages{{specify|date=January 2015}} with a similar vowel. {{Arabic alphabet shapes|ÛŠ}} {{IPAslink|Ê‰Ë}} in [[Southern Kurdish]]. {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Û}} In [[Jawi script]]: Used for {{IPAslink|v}}. ===Other letters=== See [[Arabic script in Unicode#Arabic|Arabic script in Unicode]] ==Hebrew Waw== {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" |- !colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various print fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive

(Hebrew: Vav Itsurit {{Hebrew|×•×³ ×¢×™×¦×•×¨×™×ª}}) |rowspan=3|/v/, /w/ |rowspan=3|{{IPAblink|v}}, {{IPAblink|w}} |rowspan=3|'''v'''ote
'''w'''all |- |as middle letter:{{Hebrew|×•×•}} |- |as final letter:{{Hebrew|×•}} or {{Hebrew|×™×•}} |- | {{Hebrew|×•Ö¼}} | {{Hebrew|×•}} |Vav Shruka ({{IPA|[vÃ¤v ÊƒruËˆkÃ¤]}} / {{Hebrew|×•×³ ×©×¨×•×§×”}}) or
Shuruq ({{IPA|[ÊƒuËˆruk]}} / {{Hebrew|×©××•Ö¼×¨×•Ö¼×§}})||/u/||{{IPAblink|u}}||gl'''ue''' |- | {{Hebrew|×•Ö¹}} | {{Hebrew|×•}} |Vav Chaluma ({{IPA|[vÃ¤v Ï‡Ã¤luËˆmÃ¤]}} / {{Hebrew|×•×³ ×—×œ×•××”}}) or
Holam Male ({{IPA|[Ï‡oÌËˆlÃ¤m maËˆleÌ]}} / {{Hebrew|×—×•Ö¹×œÖ¸× ×Ö¸×œÖµ×}})||/o/||{{IPAblink|oÌ}}||n'''o''', n'''oh''' |} In modern Hebrew, the frequency of the usage of vav, out of all the letters, is about 10.00%. ====Vav as consonant==== Consonantal vav ({{script/Hebrew|×•}}) generally represents a [[voiced labiodental fricative]] (like the English [[v]]) in [[Ashkenazi]], European [[Sephardi]], Persian, Caucasian, Italian and [[Hebrew language|modern Israeli Hebrew]], and was originally a [[labial-velar approximant]] {{IPA|/w/}}. In modern Israeli Hebrew, some [[loanword]]s, the pronunciation of whose source contains {{IPAslink|w}}, and their [[derivation (linguistics)|derivations]], are pronounced with {{IPAblink|w}}: {{Hebrew|×•××—×“}} â€“ {{IPA|/ËˆwaÏ‡ad/}} (but: {{Hebrew|[[Wadi|×•××“×™]]}} â€“ {{IPA|/Ëˆvadi/}}). Modern Hebrew has no [[Standard language|standardized]] way to distinguish [[Orthography|orthographically]] between {{IPAblink|v}} and {{IPAblink|w}}. The pronunciation is determined by prior knowledge or must be derived through context. Some non [[linguistic prescription|standard]] spellings of the sound {{IPAblink|w}} are sometimes found in modern Hebrew texts, such as word-initial double-vav: {{Hebrew|×•×•××œ×œ×”}} â€“ {{IPA|/Ëˆwala/}} (word-''medial'' double-vav is both standard and common for both {{IPAslink|v}} and {{IPAslink|w}}, see [[#Pronunciation in Modern Hebrew|table]] above) or, rarely, vav with a [[geresh]]: {{Hebrew|×•×³×™×œ×™××}} â€“ {{IPA|/Ëˆwiljam/}}. ====Vav with a dot on top==== {{Main|Holam}} Vav can be used as a [[mater lectionis]] for an ''o'' vowel, in which case it is known as a ''[[holam male|{{transl|he|á¸¥olam male}}]]'', which in pointed text is marked as vav with a dot above it. It is pronounced {{IPAblink|oÌ}} ([[phonemic transcription|phonemically transcribed]] more simply as {{IPA|/o/}}). The distinction is normally ignored, and the HEBREW POINT HOLAM (U+05B9) is used in all cases. The vowel can be denoted without the vav, as just the dot placed above and to the left of the letter it points, and it is then called ''[[holam haser|{{transl|he|á¸¥olam á¸¥aser}}]]''. Some inadequate typefaces do not support the distinction between the ''{{transl|he|á¸¥olam male}}'' âŸ¨{{Hebrew|×•ֹ}}âŸ© {{IPA|/o/}}, the consonantal vav pointed with a ''{{transl|he|á¸¥olam á¸¥aser}}'' âŸ¨{{Hebrew|×•ֺ}}âŸ© {{IPA|/vo/}} (compare ''{{transl|he|á¸¥olam male}}'' âŸ¨{{Hebrew|×Ö·×¦Ö¼×•ֹ×ª}}âŸ© {{IPA|/maËˆts'''o'''t/}} and consonantal vav-''{{transl|he|á¸¥olam á¸¥aser}}'' âŸ¨{{Hebrew|×Ö´×¦Ö°×•ֺ×ª}}âŸ© {{IPA|/mitsËˆ'''vo'''t/}}). To display a consonantal vav with ''{{transl|he|á¸¥olam á¸¥aser}}'' correctly, the typeface must either support the vav with the Unicode combining character "HEBREW POINT HOLAM HASER FOR VAV" (U+05BA, HTML Entity (decimal) ֺ){{cite web|url=https://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/05ba/fontsupport.htm |title=List of fonts that support U+05BA at |publisher=Fileformat.info |date= |accessdate=2013-04-11}} or the precomposed character {{Hebrew|וֹ}} (U+FB4B). * Compare the three: *# The vav with the combining character HEBREW POINT HOLAM: {{Hebrew|×Ö´×¦Ö°×•ֹ×ª}} *# The vav with the combining character HEBREW POINT HOLAM HASER FOR VAV: {{Hebrew|×Ö´×¦Ö°×•ֺ×ª}} *# The precomposed character: {{Hebrew|×Ö´×¦Ö°וֹ×ª}} ====Vav with a dot in the middle==== {{Main|Shuruk}} Vav can also be used as a ''mater lectionis'' for {{IPAblink|u}}, in which case it is known as a ''[[shuruk]]'', and in text with [[niqqud]] is marked with a dot in the middle (on the left side). [[Shuruk]] and vav with a [[dagesh]] look identical ("{{Hebrew|×•Ö¼}}") and are only distinguishable through the fact that in text with niqqud, vav with a [[dagesh]] will normally be attributed a vocal point in addition, e.g. {{Hebrew|×©××•Ö¼×§}} ({{IPA|/Êƒuk/}}), "a market", (the "{{Hebrew|×•Ö¼}}" denotes a [[shuruk]]) as opposed to {{Hebrew|×©Ö´××•ÖµÖ¼×§}} ({{IPA|/ÊƒiËˆvek/}}), "to market" (the "{{Hebrew|×•Ö¼}}" denotes a vav with [[dagesh]] and is additionally pointed with a [[zeire]], " {{Hebrew|Öµ}} ", denoting {{IPA|/e/}}). In the word {{Hebrew|×©Ö´××•Ö¼×•Ö¼×§}} ({{IPA|/ÊƒiËˆvuk/}}), "marketing", the first ("{{Hebrew|×•Ö¼}}") denotes a vav with dagesh, the second a shuruk, being the vowel attributed to the first. ===Numerical value=== Vav in [[gematria]] represents the number six, and when used at the beginning of [[Hebrew calendar|Hebrew years]], it means 6000 (i.e. {{lang|he|×•×ª×©× ×“}} in [[Arabic numerals|numbers]] would be the [[Calendar date|date]] 6754.) ===Words written as vav=== {{main|Hebrew grammar}} Vav at the beginning of the word has several possible meanings: * ''[[waw-conjunctive|vav conjunctive]]'' (Vav Hachibur, literally "the Vav of Connection"â€”chibur means "joining, or bringing together") is a vav connecting two words or parts of a sentence; it is a [[grammatical conjunction]] meaning '' 'and' '', cognate to the Arabic. This is the most common usage. * ''[[waw-consecutive|vav consecutive]]'' (Vav Hahipuch, literally "the Vav of Reversal"â€”hipuch means "inversion"), mainly biblical, commonly mistaken for the previous type of vav; it indicates consequence of actions and reverses the tense of the verb following it: **when placed in front of a verb in the imperfect tense, it changes the verb to the perfect tense. For example, ''yomar'' means 'he will say' and ''vayomar'' means 'he said'; **when placed in front of a verb in the perfect, it changes the verb to the imperfect tense. For example, ''ahavtah'' means 'you loved', and ''ve'ahavtah'' means 'you will love'. (Note: Older Hebrew did not have "tense" in a temporal sense, "perfect," and "imperfect" instead denoting aspect of completed or continuing action. Modern Hebrew verbal tenses have developed closer to their Indo-European counterparts, mostly having a temporal quality rather than denoting aspect. As a rule, Modern Hebrew does not use the "Vav Consecutive" form.) * ''[[waw-explicative|vav explicative]]'' ===Yiddish=== In [[Yiddish]],{{cite book|last=Weinreich|first=Uriel|date=1992|title=College Yiddish|location=New York|publisher=[[YIVO]] Institute for Jewish Research|pages=27â€“8|author-link=Uriel Weinreich}} the letter (known as '''vov''') is used for several orthographic purposes in native words: * Alone, a single vov {{script/Hebrew|×•}} represents the vowel {{IPAblink|u}} in standard Yiddish. * The [[digraph (orthography)|digraph]] {{script/Hebrew|×•×•}}, "''tsvey vovn''" ('two vovs'), represents the consonant {{IPAblink|v}}. * The digraph {{script/Hebrew|×•×™}}, consisting of a vov followed by a [[yodh|yud]], represents the diphthong [{{IPA|oj}}]. The single vov may be written with a dot on the left when necessary to avoid ambiguity and distinguish it from other functions of the letter. For example, the word ''vu'' 'where' is spelled {{script/Hebrew|×•×•×•Ö¼}}, as ''tsvey vovn'' followed by a single vov; the single vov indicating {{IPAblink|u}} is marked with a dot in order to distinguish which of the three vovs represents the vowel. Some texts instead separate the digraph from the single vov with a silent [[aleph]]. [[Loanword]]s from Hebrew or Aramaic in Yiddish are spelled as they are in their language of origin. ==Syriac Waw== {| class="wikitable" |- !'''Waw''' |- | [[File:Syriac Eastern waw.svg|50px]] ''Madná¸«aya'' Waw |- | [[File:Syriac Estrangela waw.svg|50px]] ''Será¹­o'' Waw |- | [[File:Syriac Serta waw.svg|50px]] ''Esá¹­rangela'' Waw |} [[File:Syriac letter shapes Waw.PNG|600px]] In the Syriac alphabet, the sixth letter is Ü˜. Waw (Ü˜ÜÜ˜) is pronounced [w]. When it is used as a mater lectionis, a waw with a dot ''above'' the letter is pronounced [o], and a waw with a dot under the letter is pronounced [u]. Was has an alphabetic-numeral value of 6. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D5|name1=Hebrew Letter Vav |0648|name2=Arabic Letter Waw |0718|name3=Syriac Letter Waw |0805|name4=Samaritan Letter Baa |FB35|name5=Hebrew Letter Vav With Dagesh |FB4B|name6=Hebrew Letter Vav With Holam }} {{charmap |10386|name1=Ugaritic Letter Wo |10845|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter Waw |10905|name3=Phoenician Letter Wau }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|×•}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Arabic language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]] [[Category:Vowel letters]] [[Category:Graphemes]]

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}}{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Redirect|Yudh}} {{Infobox Semitic letter|letname=Yodh|previouslink=Teth|previousletter=Tet|nextlink=Kaph|nextletter=Kaph|archar=ÙŠÙ€,ÙŠ‎[[#Arabic yÄÊ¼|[note] ]]|sychar= Ü|hechar=×™|amchar=yod|gechar=á‹¨|phchar=yodh|grchar=Î™|lachar=I J|cychar=Ğ†|ipa=j, i, e|num=10|gem=10}} '''Yodh''' (also spelled '''yud''', '''yod''', '''jod''', or '''jodh''') is the tenth [[Letter (alphabet)|letter]] of the Semitic [[abjad]]s, including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] YÅd [[File:Phoenician_yodh.svg|10px]], [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]] YÅd {{Lang|he|×™}}, [[Aramaic alphabet|Aramaic]] Yodh [[File:Yod.svg|10 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] YÅá¸ Ü, and [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] {{transl|ar|DIN|YÄÊ¾}} {{lang|ar|ÙŠ}} (first in [[abjad numerals|abjadi order]], but last in modern order). Its sound value is {{IPAslink|j}} in all languages for which it is used; in many languages, it also serves as a [[vowel length|long vowel]], representing {{IPAslink|i|iË}}. The Phoenician letter gave rise to the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[Iota]] (Î™),Victor Parker, ''A History of Greece, 1300 to 30 BC'', (John Wiley & Sons, 2014), 67. [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[I]], [[J]], [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[Dotted I (Cyrillic)|Ğ†]], [[Coptic alphabet|Coptic]] iauda (â²’) and [[Gothic alphabet|Gothic]] [[isaz|eis]] [[File:Gothic_letter_eis.svg|4px]]. ==Origins== Yodh is originated from a pictograph of a â€œhandâ€ that ultimately derives from [[Proto-Semitic language|Proto-Semitic]] [[:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Semitic/yad-|*yad-]]. It may be related to the Egyptian [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|hieroglyph]] of an â€œarmâ€ or â€œhandâ€ D36 ==Arabic yÄÊ¼== {{Infobox grapheme |name=YÄÊ¾ |letter=ÙŠ |variations= |image= |imagesize=200 |imagealt= |script=[[Arabic script]] |type=[[Abjad]] |typedesc= |language=[[Arabic language]] |phonemes={{IPAblink|j}}, {{IPAblink|iË}} |unicode= |alphanumber=4 |number= |usageperiod= |children= |equivalents= |associates= |direction=Right-to-left }} The letter {{lang|ar|ÙŠ}} is named ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yÄÊ¼}}'' ({{lang|ar|ÙŠÙØ§Ø¡}}). It is written in several ways depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|ÙŠ}} It is pronounced in four ways: * As a consonant, it is pronounced as a [[palatal approximant]] '''{{IPA|/j/}}''', typically at the beginnings of words in front of short or long vowels. *A [[vowel length|long]] '''{{IPA|/iË/}}''' usually in the middle or end of words. In this case it has no diacritic, but could be marked with a [[Kasrah|kasra]] in the preceding letter in some traditions. *A [[vowel length|long]] '''{{IPA|/eË/}}''' In many [[varieties of Arabic|dialects]], as a result of the [[monophthong]]ization that underwent the diphthong {{IPA|/aj/}} in most of the words. * A part of a [[diphthong]], '''{{IPA|/aj/}}'''. Then, it has no diacritic but could be marked with a sukun in some traditions. The preceding consonant could have no diacritic or have {{transl|ar|DIN|[[Fatha|fatá¸¥a]]}} sign, hinting to the first vowel in the diphthong, i.e. {{IPA|/a/}}. As a vowel, yÄÊ¾ can serve as the "seat" of the [[hamza]]: {{lang|ar|Ø¦}} YÄÊ¾ serves several functions in the Arabic language. YÄÊ¾ as a prefix is the marker for a singular [[imperfective aspect|imperfective]] verb, as in {{lang|ar|ÙŠÙÙƒÙ’ØªÙØ¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|yaktub}}'' "he writes" from the root {{lang|ar|Ùƒ-Øª-Ø¨}} K-T-B ("write, writing"). YÄÊ¾ with a [[shadda]] is particularly used to turn a noun into an adjective, called a ''nisbah'' ({{lang|ar|Ù†ÙØ³Ù’Ø¨ÙØ©}}). For instance, {{lang|ar|Ù…ÙØµÙ’Ø±}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Miá¹£r}}'' ([[Egypt]]) â†’ {{lang|ar|Ù…ÙØµÙ’Ø±ÙÙŠÙ‘}} ''Miá¹£riyy'' (Egyptian). The transformation can be more abstract; for instance, {{lang|ar|Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¶ÙÙˆØ¹}} ''mawá¸Å«Ê¿'' (matter, object) â†’ {{lang|ar|Ù…ÙÙˆÙ’Ø¶ÙÙˆØ¹ÙÙŠÙ‘}} ''mawá¸Å«Ê¿iyy'' ([[wikt:objectivity|objective]]). Still other uses of this function can be a bit further from the root: {{lang|ar|Ø¥ÙØ´Ù’ØªÙØ±ÙØ§Ùƒ}} ''ishtirÄk'' (cooperation) â†’ {{lang|ar|Ø¥ÙØ´Ù’ØªÙØ±ÙØ§ÙƒÙÙŠÙ‘}} ''ishtirÄkiyy'' ([[socialism|socialist]]). The common pronunciation of the final {{IPA|/-ijj/}} is most often pronounced as {{IPA-ar|i|}} or {{IPA-ar|iË|}}. A form similar to but distinguished from yÄÊ¾ is the ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ê¾alif maqá¹£Å«rah}}'' ({{lang|ar|Ø£ÙÙ„ÙÙ Ù…ÙÙ‚Ù’ØµÙÙˆØ±ÙØ©}}) "limited/restricted [[aleph|alif]]", with the form {{lang|ar|Ù‰}}. It indicates a final long {{IPA|/aË/}}. In Egypt, Sudan and sometimes the [[Maghreb]], the final form is always {{lang|ar|Ù‰}} (without dots), both in handwriting and in print, representing both final {{IPA|/-iË/}} and {{IPA|/-aË/}}. {{lang|ar|Ù‰}} representing final {{IPA|/-aË/}} ([[DIN 31635]] transliteration: {{transl|ar|DIN|Ä}}) is less likely to occur in Modern Standard Arabic. In this case, it is commonly known as, especially in Egypt, {{lang|ar|Ø£ÙÙ„ÙÙ Ù„ÙÙŠÙÙ‘Ù†ÙØ©}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ê¾alif layyinah}}'' {{IPA-arz|ËˆÊ”Ã¦lef lÃ¦jËˆjenÃ¦|}}. In Egypt, it is always short {{IPA|[-Ã¦, -É‘]}} if used in [[Egyptian Arabic]] and most commonly short in Modern Standard Arabic, as well. === Alif maqá¹£Å«rah === {{Anchor|alifmaqsura}}The ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maqá¹£Å«rah}}'' ({{lang|ar|Ø£Ù„Ù Ù…Ù‚ØµÙˆØ±Ø©}}, 'limited/restricted alif'), commonly known in Egypt as ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif layyinah}}'' ({{lang|ar|Ø£Ù„Ù Ù„ÙŠÙ†Ø©}}, 'flexible alif'), looks like a dotless [[Ya'|{{transl|ar|ALA|yÄâ€™}}]] {{lang|ar|Ù‰}} (final {{lang|ar|Ù€Ù‰}}) and may appear only at the end of a word. Although it looks different from a regular ''alif'', it represents the same sound {{IPA|/aË/}}, often realized as a short vowel. When it is written, ''{{transl|ar|ALA|alif maqá¹£Å«rah}}'' is indistinguishable from final [[Persian alphabet|Persian]] ''[[Yodh#Perso-Arabic ye|ye]]'' or Arabic ''{{transl|ar|ALA|yÄâ€™}}'' as it is written in Egypt, Sudan and sometimes elsewhere. The letter is transliterated as {{transl|ar|ALA|y}} in [[Kazakh language|Kazakh]]. ''{{transl|ar|ALA|Alif maqsurah}}'' is transliterated as {{transl|ar|ALA|Ã¡}} in [[ALA-LC Romanization|ALA-LC]], {{transl|ar|DIN|Ä}} in [[DIN 31635]], {{transl|ar|ISO|Ã }} in ISO 233-2, and {{transl|ar|ISO|á»³}} in [[ISO 233]]. ''In Arabic, Alif maqsurah'' {{lang|ar|Ù‰}} is not used initially or medially, and it is not joinable initially or medially in all fonts. However, the letter is used initially and medially in the [[Uyghur Arabic alphabet]] and the Arabic-based [[Kyrgyz alphabet]]: ({{script/Arabic|Ù‰Ù€ Ù€Ù‰Ù€}}).{{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ù‰}} ===Perso-Arabic ye=== {{Arabic script sidebar|Pashto|nav=no}} {{Arabic script sidebar|Persian|nav=no}} In the [[Persian alphabet]], the letter is generally called ''ye'' following [[Persian language|Persian-language]] custom. In its final form, the letter does not have dots ({{lang|fa|ÛŒ}}), much like the Arabic ''{{transl|ar|DIN|[[Aleph#Alif maqá¹£Å«rah: Ù‰|Alif maqá¹£Å«rah]]}}'' or, more to the point, much like the custom in Egypt, Sudan and sometimes Maghreb. On account of this difference, Perso-Arabic ''ye'' is located at a different [[Unicode]] [[code point]] than both of the standard Arabic letters. In computers, the Persian version of the letter automatically appears with two dots initially and medially: ({{lang|fa|ÛŒÙ€ Ù€ÛŒÙ€ Ù€ÛŒ}}). {{Arabic alphabet shapes|ÛŒ}} In [[Kashmiri language|Kashmiri]], it uses a ring instead from ÙŠ of a dots below ({{script/Arabic|Ø  Ø Ù€ Ù€Ø Ù€ Ù€Ø }}). {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø }} === Returned yÄÊ¾ === In different calligraphic styles like the [[Hijazi script]], [[Kufic]], and [[NastaÊ¿lÄ«q script]], a final ''yÄÊ¾'' might have a particular shape with the descender turned to the right ({{Nastaliq|Ù€Û’}}), called ''al-yÄÊ¾ al-mardÅ«dah/al-rÄjiÊ¿ah'' ("returned, recurred ''yÄÊ¾''"),{{cite book|last1=Gacek|first1=Adam|title=The Arabic manuscript tradition: a glossary of technical terms and bibliography: supplement|date=2008|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden|isbn=9004165401|page=29|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GfZYCcOL8dYC&pg=PA29}} either with two dots or without them.{{cite book|last1=YÅ«sofÄ«|first1=á¸ olÄm-á¸¤osayn|title=EncyclopÃ¦dia Iranica|date=1990|volume=IV|pages=680â€“704|chapter-url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/calligraphy|chapter=Calligraphy}} In [[Urdu alphabet|Urdu]] this is called ''[[baá¹›Ä« ye]]'' ("big ye"), but is an independent letter used for /É›Ë, eË/ and differs from the basic ye (''choá¹­Ä« ye'', "little ye"). For this reason the letter has its own [[code point]] in Unicode. Nevertheless, its initial and medial forms are not different from the other ''ye'' (practically ''baá¹›Ä« ye'' is not used in these positions). {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Û’}} == Hebrew Yud == {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center;" !colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various print fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew|Cursive
Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi script|Rashi

[[Monospaced]] |- |width=20%|×™ |width=20%|×™ |width=20%|×™ |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Yud handwriting.svg|38px]] |width=20%|[[File:Hebrew letter Yud Rashi.png|45px]] |} Hebrew spelling: {{lang|he|×™×•Ö¹×“}} ;[http://morfix.mako.co.il/default.aspx?q=%u05D9%u05D5%u05D3 Morfix.mako.co.il]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}[https://www.fileformat.info/info/unicode/char/05d9/index.htm Fileformat.info] colloquial {{lang|he|×™×•Ö¼×“}} ===Pronunciation=== In both Biblical and modern [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]], Yud represents a [[palatal approximant]] ({{IPAblink|j}}). As a [[mater lectionis]], it represents the vowel {{IPAblink|i}}. At the end of words with a vowel or when marked with a [[Shva#Shva Na.E1.B8.A5|sh'va nach]], it represents the formation of a [[diphthong]], such as {{IPA|/ei/}}, {{IPA|/ai/}}, or {{IPA|/oi/}}. ===Significance=== In [[gematria]], Yud represents the number ten. As a [[Prefix (linguistics)|prefix]], it designates the third person singular (or plural, with a [[Waw (letter)|Vav]] as a [[suffix]]) in the future tense. As a [[suffix]], it indicates first person singular possessive; ''av'' (father) becomes ''avi'' (my father). "Yod" in the Hebrew language signifies [[iodine]]. Iodine is also called ÙŠÙˆØ¯ ''yod'' in Arabic. ====In religion==== Two Yuds in a row designate the name of God [[Names of God in Judaism#Adonai|Adonai]] and in pointed texts are written with the vowels of Adonai; this is done as well with the [[Tetragrammaton]]. As Yud is the smallest letter, much [[Kabbalah|kabbalistic]] and mystical significance is attached to it. According to the [[Gospel of Matthew]], [[Jesus]] mentioned it during the [[Matthew 5#Antitheses|Antithesis of the Law]], when he says: "One jot or one tittle shall in no wise pass from the law, till all be fulfilled." Jot, or iota, refers to the letter Yud; it was often overlooked by scribes because of its size and position as a [[mater lectionis]]. In modern Hebrew, the phrase "tip of the Yud" refers to a small and insignificant thing, and someone who "worries about the tip of a Yud" is someone who is picky and meticulous about small details. Much [[Kabbalah|kabbalistic]] and mystical significance is also attached to it because of its gematria value as ten, which is an important number in Judaism, and its place in the name of God.[http://www.inner.org/hebleter/yud.htm Inner.org] ===Yiddish=== In [[Yiddish]],{{cite book|last=Weinreich|first=Uriel|date=1992|title=College Yiddish|location=New York|publisher=[[YIVO]] Institute for Jewish Research|pages=27â€“8|author-link=Uriel Weinreich}} the letter yud is used for several orthographic purposes in native words: * Alone, a single yud ×™ may represent the vowel {{IPAblink|i}} or the consonant {{IPAblink|j}}. When adjacent to another vowel, or another yud, {{IPAblink|i}} may be distinguished from {{IPAblink|j}} by the addition of a dot below. Thus the word ''Yidish'' 'Yiddish' is spelled ×™×™Ö´×“×™×©. The first yud represents [{{IPA|j}}]; the second yud represents [{{IPA|i}}] and is distinguished from the adjacent [{{IPA|j}}] by a dot; the third yud represents [{{IPA|i}}] as well, but no dot is necessary. * The [[digraph (orthography)|digraph]] ×™×™, consisting of two yuds, represents the diphthong [{{IPA|ej}}]. * A pair of yuds with a horizontal line (''[[patach|pasekh]]'') under them, ×²Ö·, represents the diphthong [{{IPA|aj}}] in standard Yiddish. * The digraph consisting of a [[Waw (letter)|vov]] followed by a yud, ×•×™, represents the diphthong [{{IPA|oj}}]. [[Loanword]]s from Hebrew or Aramaic in Yiddish are spelled as they are in their language of origin. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D9|name1=Hebrew Letter Yod |064A|name2=Arabic Letter Yeh |06CC|name3=Persian Letter Ye |071D|name4=Syriac Letter Yudh |0809|name5=Samaritan Letter Yut }} {{charmap |1038A|name1=Ugaritic Letter Yod |10849|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter Yodh |10909|name3=Phoenician Letter Yod }} ==See also== *[[Phonological history of English consonant clusters#Yod-dropping]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|×™}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Arabic language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]] [[Category:Vowel letters]] [[Category:Graphemes]]

pages.title: Zayin
pages.text: {{About|Semitic letter|other uses|Zayn (disambiguation){{!}}Zayn}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2009}} {{Phoenician glyph|letname=Zayin|previouslink=Waw (letter)|previousletter=Waw|nextlink=Heth|nextletter=Het|archar={{lang|ar|Ø²}}|sychar=Ü™|hechar={{Hebrew|×–}}|amchar=zayin|gechar=á‹˜|phchar=zayin|grchar=Î–|lachar=Z|cychar=Ğ—|ipa=z|num=7|gem=7}} '''Zayin''' (also spelled '''zain''' or '''zayn''' or simply '''zay''') is the seventh letter of the [[Semitic abjads]], including [[Phoenician alphabet|Phoenician]] Zayin [[File:Phoenician_zayin.svg|10px|]], [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] 'Zayin {{Hebrew|×–}}, [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]] Zoyen {{Hebrew|×–}}, [[Aramaic language|Aramaic]] Zain [[File:Zayin.svg| 10 px]], [[Syriac alphabet|Syriac]] Zayn Ü™, and [[Arabic alphabet|Arabic]] Zayn or ZÄy {{lang|ar|Ø²}}. It represents the sound {{IPAblink|z}}. The Phoenician letter gave rise to the [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] [[Zeta (letter)|zeta]] (Î–), [[Etruscan alphabet|Etruscan]] ''z'' [[File:EtruscanZ-01.png|14px|Z]], [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] [[Z]], and [[Cyrillic script|Cyrillic]] [[Ze (Cyrillic)|Ze]] Ğ—. ==Original and modern meaning of the noun 'zayin'== The Phoenician letter appears to be named after a sword or other weapon. In [[Biblical Hebrew]], ''{{transl|he|zayin}}'' ({{script/Hebrew|×–×™×Ÿ}}) means "sword", and the verb ''{{transl|he|lezayen}}'' ({{script/Hebrew|×œ×–×™×™×Ÿ}}) means "to arm". In [[Modern Hebrew]] [[slang]], ''{{transl|he|zayin}}'' ({{script/Hebrew|×–×™×Ÿ}}) means "[[penis]]" and ''{{transl|he|lezayen}}'' ({{script/Hebrew|×œ×–×™×Ÿ}}) is a vulgar term which generally means to perform [[sexual intercourse]] ,{{cite web |url= http://morfix.mako.co.il/en/default.aspx?q=%D7%96%D7%99%D7%9F&source=milon|title=Definition of ×–×™×Ÿ in Modern Hebrew, Milon Morfix (en)}}{{cite news|author= Michael Handelzalts |date= 15 October 2013 |url= https://www.haaretz.com/archaeology/.premium-how-zayin-came-to-mean-arms-and-penis-1.5273875 |title= How a Hebrew letter came to mean both "penis" and "weapon" |newspaper= Haaretz |access-date=11 November 2018}} although the older meaning survives in ''{{transl|he|maavak mezuyan}}'' ("armed struggle") ({{script/Hebrew|×××‘×§ ××–×•×™×Ÿ}}), ''{{transl|he|kokhot mezuyanim}}'' ("armed forces") ({{script/Hebrew|×›×•×—×•×ª ××–×•×™× ×™×}}), and ''{{transl|he|beton mezuyan}}'' ({{script/Hebrew|×‘×˜×•×Ÿ ××–×•×™×Ÿ}}) ("armed, i.e., reinforced [[concrete]]"). The [[Proto-Sinaitic]] glyph may have been called ''ziqq'', based on a [[Egyptian hieroglyphs|hieroglyph]] depicting a "[[manacle]]".Brian E. Colless, [https://sites.google.com/site/collesseum/cuneiformalphabet Cuneiform Alphabet] ==Arabic zÄy == The letter is named {{transl|ar|ALA|zÄy}}. It has two forms, depending on its position in the word: {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ø²}} The similarity to ''{{transl|ar|ALA|rÄÊ¼ }}'' {{lang|ar|[[Resh#Arabic rÄÊ¾|Ø±]]}}  is likely a function of the original Syriac forms converging to a single symbol, requiring that one of them be distinguished as a dot; a similar process occurred to [[Gimel (letter)|{{transl|ar|ALA|jÄ«m}}]] and [[Heth (letter)|{{transl|ar|ALA|á¸¥ÄÊ¼}}]]. {{anchor|Ze}} {{Arabic-script sidebar|Persian}} The same letter has another name â€“ ''ze'' â€“ in a number of languages, such as Persian. ===Å½e=== {{main|Ú˜}} It also has a modified version: {{lang|fa|[[Ú˜]]}} {{IPA-fa|Ê’e}}, which is used in [[Persian language|Persian]], [[Pashto language|Pashto]], [[Kurdish language|Kurdish]], [[Urdu]] and [[Uyghur language|Uyghur]] (see [[Uyghur Ereb YÃ©ziqi|KÌ¡ona YezikÌ¡]]). {{Arabic alphabet shapes|Ú˜}} ==Hebrew zayin== {|class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" !colspan=5|[[Orthography|Orthographic]] variants |- !colspan=3|Various print fonts !rowspan=2|[[Cursive Hebrew]] !rowspan=2|[[Rashi script]] |- !Serif !! [[Sans-serif]] !! [[Monospaced]] |- |width=20%|×– |style="font:28pt Arial, 'DejaVu Sans Condensed', 'DejaVu Sans', Tahoma, Alef, sans-serif;"|×– |style="font:30pt 'Courier New', 'Miriam Fixed', FreeMono, monospace;"|×– |[[File:Hebrew letter Zayin handwriting.svg|22px]] |[[File:Hebrew letter Zayin Rashi.png|35px]] |} In modern Hebrew the frequency of the usage of zayin, out of all the letters, is 0.88%. Hebrew spelling: {{lang|he|×–Ö·×™Ö´×Ÿ}} In modern Hebrew, the combination {{Hebrew|×–×³}} (zayin followed by a [[geresh]]) is used in loanwords and foreign names to denote {{IPAblink|Ê’}} as in ''vi{{strong|si}}on''. ===Significance=== ====Numerical value (gematria)==== In [[gematria]], zayin represents the number [[7|seven]],{{cite web|url=http://www.inner.org/gematria/gemchart.htm|title=Gematria Chart}} and when used at the beginning of [[Hebrew calendar|Hebrew years]] it means 7000 (i.e. {{lang|he|×–×ª×©× ×“}} in [[Arabic numerals|numbers]] would be the future [[Calendar date|date]] 7754). ====Use in Torah scroll==== Zayin is also one of the seven letters which receive a special crown (called a ''[[Tagin (Hebrew writing)|tagin]]'') when written in a [[Sefer Torah]] (Torah scroll), besides [[Ê»ayin]], [[gimel]], [[teth]], [[Nun (letter)|nun]], [[Shin (letter)|shin]], and [[Tzade|tzadi]]. ====Meaning as a noun==== For the Biblical and Modern Hebrew meaning of 'zayin' as a noun, see [[Zayin#Original and modern meaning of the noun 'zayin'|above]]. It is one of several Hebrew letters that have an additional meaning as a noun. The others are: [[bet (letter)|bet]] [{{Hebrew|×‘}}, the 2nd letter], whose name is a grammatical form of the word for 'house' ({{lang|he|×‘×™×ª}}); [[vav (letter)|vav]] [{{Hebrew|×•}}, the 6th letter], whose name means 'hook' ({{lang|he|×•×•}}); [[kaph|kaf]] [{{Hebrew|×›}}, the 11th], whose name means 'palm [of the hand]' or 'tablespoon' ({{lang|he|×›×£}}); Ê»ayin [{{Hebrew|×¢}}, the 16th], whose name means 'eye' ({{lang|he|×¢×™×Ÿ}}); pe [{{Hebrew|×¤}}, the 17th], whose name means 'mouth' ({{lang|he|×¤×”}}); [[qoph|qof]] [{{Hebrew|×§}}, the 19th], whose name means 'monkey' or "eye of needle" ({{lang|he|×§×•×£}}); [[tav (letter)|tav]] [{{Hebrew|×ª}}, the 22nd], whose name means 'mark' ({{lang|he|×ª×•}}), and several other Hebrew letters, whose names are ancient Hebrew forms of nouns still used, with a slight change of form or pronunciation, as nouns in modern Hebrew.{{cite web|url=http://morfix.mako.co.il/en/Default.aspx?hl=en|title=Milon Morfix (en)}} ==Syriac zain== Zain is a consonant with the {{ipa|/z/}} sound which is a [[voiced alveolar fricative]]. ==Character encodings== {{charmap |05D6|name1=Hebrew Letter Zayin |0632|name2=Arabic Letter Zain |0719|name3=Syriac Letter Zain |0806|name4=Samaritan Letter Zen }} {{charmap |10387|name1=Ugaritic Letter Zeta |10846|name2=Imperial Aramaic Letter Zayin |10906|name3=Phoenician Letter Zai }} == See also == *[[Ve (Arabic)|Ú¤ - Ve]] *[[Pe (Arabic)|Ù¾ - Pe]] *[[Gaf|Ú¯ - GÄf]] *[[Che (Arabic)|Ú† - Che]] ==References== {{commonscat|×–}} {{Reflist}} {{Arabic language}} {{Hebrew language}} {{Northwest Semitic abjad}} [[Category:Phoenician alphabet]] [[Category:Arabic letters]] [[Category:Hebrew alphabet]]

Letters in black, [[Niqqud|pointing]] in red, [[cantillation]] in blue[[Cantillation]] ]] [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] [[orthography]] includes three types of [[diacritic]]s: * ''[[Niqqud]]'' in Hebrew is the way to indicate vowels, which are omitted in modern orthography, using a set of ancillary glyphs. Since the vowels can be understood from surrounding, context can help readers read the correct pronunciations of several letters of the [[Hebrew alphabet]] (the [[rafe (diacritic)|rafe]] sign and other rare glyphs are also listed as part of the niqqud system but are not in common use){{ref label|rafe|*|}}; * ''[[geresh]]'' and ''[[gershayim]],'' two diacritics that are not considered a part of niqqud, each of which has several functions (e.g. to denote [[Hebrew numerals]]); * and ''[[cantillation]],'' "accents" which are used exclusively to indicate how Biblical passages should be chanted and may possess a punctuating function. Several diacritical systems were developed in the Early Middle Ages. The most widespread system, and the only one still used to a significant degree today, was created by the [[Masoretes]] of [[Tiberias]] in the second half of the first millennium in the [[Land of Israel]] (see [[Masoretic Text]], [[Tiberian Hebrew]]). The Niqqud signs and cantillation marks developed by the Masoretes are small compared to consonants, so they could be added to the consonantal texts without retranscribing them. ==Pointing ''(niqqud)''== {{main article|niqqud}} In modern Israeli orthography, vowel and consonant pointing is seldom used, except in specialised texts such as dictionaries, poetry, or texts for children or for new immigrants. Israeli Hebrew has five vowel phonemesâ€”{{IPAslink|i}}, {{IPAslink|eÌ|e}}, {{IPAslink|Ã¤|a}}, {{IPAslink|oÌ|o}} and {{IPAslink|u}}â€”but many more written symbols for them. Placed above a letter ( {{Hebrew|Ö}}  e.g. {{Hebrew|×¤Ö°Ö¼×¨Ö´Ö×™}}) it is one of the cantillation marks. ==Disputes among Protestant Christians== [[Protestantism|Protestant]] literalists who believe that the Hebrew text of the Old Testament is the inspired Word of God are divided on the question of whether or not the vowel points should be considered an inspired part of the Old Testament. In 1624, [[Louis Cappel]], a French [[Huguenot]] scholar at [[Saumur]], published a work in which he concluded that the vowel points were a later addition to the biblical text and that the vowel points were added not earlier than the fifth century AD. This assertion was hotly contested by Swiss theologian [[Johannes Buxtorf II]] in 1648. [[Brian Walton (bishop)|Brian Walton]]'s 1657 polyglot bible followed Cappel in revising the vowel points. In 1675, the 2nd and 3rd canons of the so-called [[Helvetic Consensus]] of the [[Swiss Reformed Church]] confirmed Buxtorf's view as orthodox and affirmed that the vowel points were inspired.{{Cn|date=February 2018}} ==See also== * [[Arabic diacritics]] * [[Q're perpetuum]] * [[Hebrew alphabet]] * [[Hebrew spelling]] ==Notes== :'''*'''{{note|rafe}} The [[rafe (diacritic)|rafe]] sign ({{Hebrew|×¨×¤×”}}, {{Hebrew| ֿ }} ) which is used to mark fricative consonants in the [[YIVO]] orthography of [[Yiddish]]; is no longer used in modern printed Hebrew. Rafe may appear in [[masoretic]] manuscripts as well as other older texts where the soft fricative consonants and sometimes [[matres lectionis]] are indicated by this sign. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.hebrew4christians.com/Grammar/Unit_Two/unit_two.html A free online course to learn the Hebrew Vowel System] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090227051707/http://hebrew-academy.huji.ac.il/decision4.html ''Rules for Spelling without Niqqud''] - a simplified version of the Rules, published on the [[Academy of the Hebrew Language]] website. *{{Cite GHG|5|m|nologo=1}} for usage of Geresh in abbreviations; {{Cite GHG|7|notitle=1}}, {{Cite GHG|8|notitle=1}}, {{Cite GHG|9|notitle=1}}, {{Cite GHG|10|notitle=1}} for vowel signs; {{Cite GHG|12|notitle=1}}, {{Cite GHG|13|notitle=1}}, {{Cite GHG|14|notitle=1}} for Dagesh, Mappiq and Rafe; {{Cite GHG|15|notitle=1}}, {{Cite GHG|16|notitle=1}} for the cantillation signs and Maqqeph. *[http://www.edu-negev.gov.il/tapuz/motytp/xadash/nikud.htm Hebrew tutorial on how to use diacritics in Word] {{selfref|'''Important:''' There is currently a serious bug affecting Hebrew diacritics in all Wikimedia projects. See [[Wikipedia:Niqqud]] for a discussion of the problem in English, and click the language link in the sidebar for an extensive analysis of the problem in Hebrew.|}} {{Hebrew language}} [[Category:Hebrew diacritics| ]]
